title: firefox update wiped out all bookmarks and history!
content:
how do I restore history and bookmark files? I have Linux mint 17.7.1 Rebecca. There was a message that there was three updates waiting (one of which was from Firefox). I got the message all three downloaded successfully and I was "up to date". My normal boot up screen was now replaced with a firefox info screen. All bookmarks and history disappeared. I am not familiar with Linux so if there is a restore to prev fix I would be grateful for a step by step fix. This same thing happened on my windows 7 os when I got an update message but that was a simple fix of just restoring to previous day. The Firefox version that is the latest offending # 78.7.1

Thank you rocketguy333@hotmail.com
creator: rocketguy333

title: How to avoid auto-refresh tab when switching tabs
content: How to avoid auto-refresh tab when switching tabs - It happens when I'm using a tab and return to a previous tab (minimized) the browser just reload it instead of show me the point where I left the page when I switch the tabs. I know that this could be changed from the about:config page but I don't know specifically what to search to change it - (I'm using Firefox Nightly on Android) - Thank you for read adn good luck!!
creator: facundosueldo

title: Firefox Insecurity?
content:
I had been using Firefox for years for privacy, but I found a blog circulating on Reddit which is ran by a security researcher who claims to debunk misinformation about security. One article is about Firefox and Chromium security[1] and the author claims that Firefox is lacking in its security, so much so that they advise people to stick to Chromium[2]. I can’t make heads or tails of it but (at least from a layman’s point of view) they seem to know what they are talking about. At the very end they even include other security researchers who seem to share the same opinion. The only potential flaw I found in the article is that they claim Firefox lacks site isolation, which seems to be true at the moment, but since Fission is now available on Firefox it looks like that will no longer be true in the near-future. However they did claim that Fission still has leaks, which might indicate that it is still a security concern.

I came to ask what others thought of these criticisms and see if they hold water. If so, does Mozilla have plans on improving the security of Firefox? In my opinion, most of Firefox’s user base is made of people who care about privacy, security, and freedom. If it’s true that Firefox has poor security, I think securing Firefox should be one of Mozilla’s top priorities before trying to add new features or create a fancier UI to appeal to the general public.

[1] https://madaidans-insecurities.github.io/firefox-chromium.html [2] https://madaidans-insecurities.github.io/security-privacy-advice.html
creator: nacknack

title: NS_ERROR_DOM_ABORT_ERR loading mail.google.com (FF88.0.1, macOS 11.4)
content:
When I navigate to mail.google.com, I get a 301 to /mail/, a 302 to https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0/, and then the error NS_ERROR_DOM_ABORT_ERR. If I navigate directly to https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0/, I immediately get the error NS_ERROR_DOM_ABORT_ERR.

Can I fix this? Thanks!
creator: Don01001100

title: Cloudflare ESNI test valid for Firefox?
content:
Cloudflare provides a web site https://www.cloudflare.com/ssl/encrypted-sni/# which can test Encrytped SNI. My browser is configured in about:config for ECH as follows

network.dns.use_https_rr_as_altsvc true network.dns.echconfig.enabled

When I run cloud flares test I get a failure for ESNI, should this occur?
creator: mace2
